segments.en: Linked Discourses 42.11
1. Chiefs
With Bhadraka

segments.pli: Ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā mallesu viharati uruvelakappaṁ nāma mallānaṁ nigamo.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town called Uruvelakappa.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhadrako gāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho bhadrako gāmaṇi bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Bhadraka the village chief went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desetū”ti.
segments.en: “Please, sir, teach me the origin and cessation of suffering.”

segments.pli: “Ahañce te, gāmaṇi, atītamaddhānaṁ ārabbha dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca deseyyaṁ:
segments.en: “Chief, if I were to teach you about the origin and ending of suffering in the past, saying

segments.pli: ‘evaṁ ahosi atītamaddhānan’ti, tatra te siyā kaṅkhā, siyā vimati.
segments.en: ‘this is how it was in the past,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.

segments.pli: Ahañce te, gāmaṇi, anāgatamaddhānaṁ ārabbha dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca deseyyaṁ:
segments.en: If I were to teach you about the origin and ending of suffering in the future, saying

segments.pli: ‘evaṁ bhavissati anāgatamaddhānan’ti, tatrāpi te siyā kaṅkhā, siyā vimati.
segments.en: ‘this is how it will be in the future,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.

segments.pli: Api cāhaṁ, gāmaṇi, idheva nisinno ettheva te nisinnassa dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desessāmi.
segments.en: Rather, chief, I will teach you about the origin and ending of suffering as I am sitting right here and you are sitting right there.

segments.pli: Taṁ suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho bhadrako gāmaṇi bhagavato paccassosi.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” Bhadraka replied.
The Buddha said this:
“What do you think, chief?

segments.pli: atthi te uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: Are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

segments.pli: “Atthi me, bhante, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ me vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.
segments.en: “There are, sir.”

segments.pli: “Atthi pana te, gāmaṇi, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: “But are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would not cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

segments.pli: “Atthi me, bhante, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ me vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.
segments.en: “There are, sir.”

segments.pli: “Ko nu kho, gāmaṇi, hetu, ko paccayo yena te ekaccānaṁ uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: “What’s the cause, chief, what’s the reason why, if this was to happen to some people it could cause you sorrow, while if it happens to others it does not?”

segments.pli: “Yesaṁ me, bhante, uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā, atthi me tesu chandarāgo.
segments.en: “The people regarding whom this would give rise to sorrow are those I have desire and passion.

segments.pli: Yesaṁ pana, bhante, uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā, natthi me tesu chandarāgo”ti.
segments.en: The people regarding whom this would not give rise to sorrow are those I don’t have desire and passion.”

segments.pli: “Iminā tvaṁ, gāmaṇi, dhammena diṭṭhena viditena akālikena pattena pariyogāḷhena atītānāgate nayaṁ nehi:
segments.en: “With this present phenomenon that is seen, known, immediate, attained, and fathomed, you may infer to the past and future:

segments.pli: ‘yaṁ kho kiñci atītamaddhānaṁ dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajji sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
segments.en: ‘All the suffering that arose in the past was rooted and sourced in desire.
For desire is the root of suffering.

segments.pli: Yampi hi kiñci anāgatamaddhānaṁ dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjissati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
segments.en: All the suffering that will arise in the future will be rooted and sourced in desire.
For desire is the root of suffering.’”
“It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!
How well said this was by the Buddha!

segments.pli: ‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
segments.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.
For desire is the root of suffering.’

segments.pli: Atthi me, bhante, ciravāsī nāma kumāro bahi āvasathe paṭivasati.
segments.en: I have a boy called Ciravāsi, who resides in a house away from here.

segments.pli: So khvāhaṁ, bhante, kālasseva vuṭṭhāya purisaṁ uyyojemi:
segments.en: I rise early and send someone, saying:
‘Go, my man, and check on my boy Ciravāsi.’

segments.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhante, so puriso nāgacchati, tassa me hoteva aññathattaṁ:
segments.en: Until they get back I worry:
‘I hope nothing’s wrong with Ciravāsi!’”
“What do you think, chief?

segments.pli: ciravāsissa kumārassa vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: If Ciravāsi was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

segments.pli: “Ciravāsissa me, bhante, kumārassa vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṁ, kiṁ pana me nuppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.
segments.en: “How could it not, sir?”
“This too is a way to understand:

segments.pli: ‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
segments.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.
For desire is the root of suffering.’
What do you think, chief?

segments.pli: yadā te ciravāsimātā adiṭṭhā ahosi, assutā ahosi, te ciravāsimātuyā chando vā rāgo vā pemaṁ vā”ti?
segments.en: Before you’d seen or heard of Ciravāsi’s mother, did you have any desire or passion or fondness for her?”
“No, sir.”

segments.pli: “Dassanaṁ vā te, gāmaṇi, āgamma savanaṁ vā evaṁ te ahosi:
segments.en: “Then was it because you saw or heard of her that you had

segments.pli: ‘ciravāsimātuyā chando vā rāgo vā pemaṁ vā’”ti?
segments.en: desire or passion or fondness for her?”
“Yes, sir.”
“What do you think, chief?

segments.pli: ciravāsimātuyā te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: If Ciravāsi’s mother was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

segments.pli: “Ciravāsimātuyā me, bhante, vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṁ, kiṁ pana me nuppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.
segments.en: “How could it not, sir?”
“This too is a way to understand:

segments.pli: ‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
segments.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.
For desire is the root of suffering.’”

segments.en: Middle Discourses 105
With Sunakkhatta
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā vesāliyaṁ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṁ.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulehi bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā hoti:
segments.en: Now at that time several mendicants had declared their enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence:

segments.pli: “‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmā”ti.
segments.en: “We understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
Sunakkhatta the Licchavi heard about this.

segments.pli: “sambahulehi kira bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā hoti:
‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’”ti.
Atha kho sunakkhatto licchaviputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho sunakkhatto licchaviputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
segments.en: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
“Sir, I have heard that

segments.pli: ‘sambahulehi kira bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā—
segments.en: several mendicants have declared their enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence.

segments.pli: khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’ti.
Ye te, bhante, bhikkhū bhagavato santike aññaṁ byākaṁsu:
‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’ti, kacci te, bhante, bhikkhū sammadeva aññaṁ byākaṁsu udāhu santetthekacce bhikkhū adhimānena aññaṁ byākaṁsū”ti?
segments.en: I trust they did so rightly—or are there some who declared enlightenment out of overestimation?”

segments.pli: “Ye te, sunakkhatta, bhikkhū mama santike aññaṁ byākaṁsu:
‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’ti.
Santetthekacce bhikkhū sammadeva aññaṁ byākaṁsu, santi panidhekacce bhikkhū adhimānenapi aññaṁ byākaṁsu.
segments.en: “Some of them did so rightly, Sunakkhatta, while others did so out of overestimation.

segments.pli: Tatra, sunakkhatta, ye te bhikkhū sammadeva aññaṁ byākaṁsu tesaṁ taṁ tatheva hoti;
segments.en: Now, when mendicants declare enlightenment rightly, that is their truth.

segments.pli: ye pana te bhikkhū adhimānena aññaṁ byākaṁsu tatra, sunakkhatta, tathāgatassa evaṁ hoti:
segments.en: But when mendicants declare enlightenment out of overestimation, the Realized One thinks:
‘I should teach them the Dhamma.’
If the Realized One thinks
he should teach them the Dhamma,

segments.pli: Atha ca panidhekacce moghapurisā pañhaṁ abhisaṅkharitvā abhisaṅkharitvā tathāgataṁ upasaṅkamitvā pucchanti.
segments.en: but then certain futile men, having carefully planned a question, approach the Realized One and ask it,

segments.pli: Tatra, sunakkhatta, yampi tathāgatassa evaṁ hoti:
segments.en: then the Realized One
changes his mind.”
“Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

segments.pli: yaṁ bhagavā dhammaṁ deseyya. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
segments.en: Let the Buddha teach the Dhamma. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

segments.pli: “Tena hi, sunakkhatta, suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: “Well then, Sunakkhatta, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho sunakkhatto licchaviputto bhagavato paccassosi.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” replied Sunakkhatta.
The Buddha said this:
“Sunakkhatta, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
What five?

segments.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā,
segments.en: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
Sounds known by the ear …
Smells known by the nose …
Tastes known by the tongue …

segments.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā—
segments.en: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṁ idhekacco purisapuggalo lokāmisādhimutto assa.
segments.en: It’s possible that a certain individual may be intent on worldly pleasures of the flesh.

segments.pli: Lokāmisādhimuttassa kho, sunakkhatta, purisapuggalassa tappatirūpī ceva kathā saṇṭhāti, tadanudhammañca anuvitakketi, anuvicāreti, tañca purisaṁ bhajati, tena ca vittiṁ āpajjati;
segments.en: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it satisfying.

segments.pli: āneñjapaṭisaṁyuttāya ca pana kathāya kacchamānāya na sussūsati, na sotaṁ odahati, na aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhāpeti, na ca taṁ purisaṁ bhajati, na ca tena vittiṁ āpajjati.
segments.en: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it satisfying.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, puriso sakamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā ciravippavuttho assa.
segments.en: Suppose a person had left their own village or town long ago,

segments.pli: So aññataraṁ purisaṁ passeyya tamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā acirapakkantaṁ.
segments.en: and they saw another person who had only recently left there.

segments.pli: So taṁ purisaṁ tassa gāmassa vā nigamassa vā khematañca subhikkhatañca appābādhatañca puccheyya;
segments.en: They would ask about whether their village was safe, with plenty of food and little disease,

segments.pli: tassa so puriso tassa gāmassa vā nigamassa vā khematañca subhikkhatañca appābādhatañca saṁseyya.
segments.en: and the other person would tell them the news.
What do you think, Sunakkhatta?

segments.pli: api nu so puriso tassa purisassa sussūseyya, sotaṁ odaheyya, aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhāpeyya, tañca purisaṁ bhajeyya, tena ca vittiṁ āpajjeyyā”ti?
segments.en: Would that person want to listen to that other person? Would they actively listen and try to understand? Would they associate with that person, and find it satisfying?”
“Yes, sir.”

segments.pli: “Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, ṭhānametaṁ vijjati yaṁ idhekacco purisapuggalo lokāmisādhimutto assa.
segments.en: “In the same way, it’s possible that a certain individual may be intent on worldly pleasures of the flesh.

segments.pli: Lokāmisādhimuttassa kho, sunakkhatta, purisapuggalassa tappatirūpī ceva kathā saṇṭhāti, tadanudhammañca anuvitakketi, anuvicāreti, tañca purisaṁ bhajati, tena ca vittiṁ āpajjati;
segments.en: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it satisfying.

segments.pli: āneñjapaṭisaṁyuttāya ca pana kathāya kacchamānāya na sussūsati, na sotaṁ odahati, na aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhāpeti, na ca taṁ purisaṁ bhajati, na ca tena vittiṁ āpajjati.
segments.en: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it satisfying.
You should know of them:
‘That individual is intent on pleasures of the flesh, for they’re detached from things connected with the imperturbable.’

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṁ idhekacco purisapuggalo āneñjādhimutto assa.
segments.en: It’s possible that a certain individual may be intent on the imperturbable.

segments.pli: Āneñjādhimuttassa kho, sunakkhatta, purisapuggalassa tappatirūpī ceva kathā saṇṭhāti, tadanudhammañca anuvitakketi, anuvicāreti, tañca purisaṁ bhajati, tena ca vittiṁ āpajjati;
segments.en: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it satisfying.

segments.pli: lokāmisapaṭisaṁyuttāya ca pana kathāya kacchamānāya na sussūsati, na sotaṁ odahati, na aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhāpeti, na ca taṁ purisaṁ bhajati, na ca tena vittiṁ āpajjati.
segments.en: But when talk connected with worldly pleasures of the flesh is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it satisfying.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, paṇḍupalāso bandhanā pavutto abhabbo haritattāya;
segments.en: Suppose there was a fallen, withered leaf. It’s incapable of becoming green again.

segments.pli: evameva kho, sunakkhatta, āneñjādhimuttassa purisapuggalassa ye lokāmisasaṁyojane se pavutte.
segments.en: In the same way, an individual intent on the imperturbable has dropped the connection with worldly pleasures of the flesh.
You should know of them:
‘That individual is intent on the imperturbable, for they’re detached from things connected with pleasures of the flesh.’

segments.pli: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṁ idhekacco purisapuggalo ākiñcaññāyatanādhimutto assa.
segments.en: It’s possible that a certain individual may be intent on the dimension of nothingness.

segments.pli: Ākiñcaññāyatanādhimuttassa kho, sunakkhatta, purisapuggalassa tappatirūpī ceva kathā saṇṭhāti, tadanudhammañca anuvitakketi, anuvicāreti, tañca purisaṁ bhajati, tena ca vittiṁ āpajjati;

segments.en: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it satisfying.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, puthusilā dvedhābhinnā appaṭisandhikā hoti;
segments.en: Suppose there was a broad rock that had been broken in half, so that it could not be put back together again.

segments.pli: evameva kho, sunakkhatta, ākiñcaññāyatanādhimuttassa purisapuggalassa ye āneñjasaṁyojane se bhinne.
segments.en: In the same way, an individual intent on the dimension of nothingness has broken the connection with the imperturbable.
You should know of them:
‘That individual is intent on the dimension of nothingness, for they’re detached from things connected with the imperturbable.’

segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Ukkaṭṭhā, in the Subhaga Forest at the root of a magnificent sal tree.

“Mendicants!”

“Mendicants, I will teach you the explanation of the root of all things.

segments.pli: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā aṅguttarāpesu viharati āpaṇaṁ nāma aṅguttarāpānaṁ nigamo.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Aṅguttarāpans, near the town of theirs named Āpaṇa.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya āpaṇaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
segments.en: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms.

segments.pli: Āpaṇe piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yenaññataro vanasaṇḍo tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
segments.en: He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to a certain forest grove for the day’s meditation.

segments.pli: Taṁ vanasaṇḍaṁ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṁ nisīdi.
segments.en: Having plunged deep into it, he sat at the root of a certain tree to meditate.

segments.pli: Āyasmāpi kho udāyī pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya āpaṇaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
segments.en: Venerable Udāyī also robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms.

segments.pli: Āpaṇe piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena so vanasaṇḍo tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
segments.en: He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to that forest grove for the day’s meditation.

segments.pli: Taṁ vanasaṇḍaṁ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṁ nisīdi.
segments.en: Having plunged deep into it, he sat at the root of a certain tree to meditate.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmato udāyissa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
segments.en: Then as Venerable Udāyī was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:

segments.pli: “bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā dukkhadhammānaṁ apahattā, bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā sukhadhammānaṁ upahattā;
segments.en: “The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!

segments.pli: bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ apahattā, bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upahattā”ti.
segments.en: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā udāyī sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā udāyī bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then in the late afternoon, Udāyī came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “idha mayhaṁ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
segments.en: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:

segments.pli: ‘bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā dukkhadhammānaṁ apahattā, bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā sukhadhammānaṁ upahattā;
segments.en: ‘The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!

segments.pli: bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ apahattā, bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upahattā’ti.
segments.en: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!’

segments.pli: Mayañhi, bhante, pubbe sāyañceva bhuñjāma pāto ca divā ca vikāle.
segments.en: For we used to eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.

segments.pli: Ahu kho so, bhante, samayo yaṁ bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: But then there came a time when the Buddha addressed the mendicants, saying,
‘Please, mendicants, give up that meal at the wrong time of day.’

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, ahudeva aññathattaṁ, ahudeva domanassaṁ:
segments.en: At that, sir, we became sad and upset,

segments.pli: ‘yampi no saddhā gahapatikā divā vikāle paṇītaṁ khādanīyaṁ bhojanīyaṁ denti tassapi no bhagavā pahānamāha, tassapi no sugato paṭinissaggamāhā’ti.
segments.en: ‘But these faithful householders give us delicious fresh and cooked foods at the wrong time of day. And the Blessed One tells us to give it up! The Holy One tells us to let it go!’

segments.pli: Te mayaṁ, bhante, bhagavati pemañca gāravañca hiriñca ottappañca sampassamānā evaṁ taṁ divāvikālabhojanaṁ pajahimhā.
segments.en: But when we considered our love and respect for the Buddha, and our sense of conscience and prudence, we gave up that meal at the wrong time of day.

segments.pli: Te mayaṁ, bhante, sāyañceva bhuñjāma pāto ca.
segments.en: Then we ate in the evening and the morning.

segments.pli: Ahu kho so, bhante, samayo yaṁ bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: But then there came a time when the Buddha addressed the mendicants, saying,
‘Please, mendicants, give up that meal at the wrong time of night.’

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, ahudeva aññathattaṁ ahudeva domanassaṁ:
segments.en: At that, sir, we became sad and upset,

segments.pli: ‘yampi no imesaṁ dvinnaṁ bhattānaṁ paṇītasaṅkhātataraṁ tassapi no bhagavā pahānamāha, tassapi no sugato paṭinissaggamāhā’ti.
segments.en: ‘But that’s considered the more delicious of the two meals. And the Blessed One tells us to give it up! The Holy One tells us to let it go!’

segments.pli: Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhante, aññataro puriso divā sūpeyyaṁ labhitvā evamāha:
segments.en: Once it so happened that a certain person got some soup during the day. He said,

segments.pli: ‘handa ca imaṁ nikkhipatha, sāyaṁ sabbeva samaggā bhuñjissāmā’ti.
segments.en: ‘Come, let’s set this aside; we’ll enjoy it together this evening.’

segments.pli: Yā kāci, bhante, saṅkhatiyo sabbā tā rattiṁ, appā divā.
segments.en: Nearly all meals are prepared at night, only a few in the day.

segments.pli: Te mayaṁ, bhante, bhagavati pemañca gāravañca hiriñca ottappañca sampassamānā evaṁ taṁ rattiṁvikālabhojanaṁ pajahimhā.
segments.en: But when we considered our love and respect for the Buddha, and our sense of conscience and prudence, we gave up that meal at the wrong time of night.

segments.pli: Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhante, bhikkhū rattandhakāratimisāyaṁ piṇḍāya carantā candanikampi pavisanti, oligallepi papatanti, kaṇṭakāvāṭampi ārohanti, suttampi gāviṁ ārohanti, māṇavehipi samāgacchanti katakammehipi akatakammehipi, mātugāmopi te asaddhammena nimanteti.
segments.en: In the past, mendicants went wandering for alms in the dark of the night. They walked into a swamp, or fell into a sewer, or collided with a thorn bush, or collided with a sleeping cow, or encountered youths escaping a crime or on their way to commit one, or were invited by a female to commit a lewd act.
Once it so happened that I was wandering for alms in the dark of the night.

segments.pli: Addasā kho maṁ, bhante, aññatarā itthī vijjantarikāya bhājanaṁ dhovantī.
segments.en: A woman washing a pot saw me by a flash of lightning.
Startled, she cried out,
‘Woe is me! It’s a damn goblin!’

segments.pli: Evaṁ vutte, ahaṁ, bhante, taṁ itthiṁ etadavocaṁ:
segments.en: When she said this, I said to her,
‘Sister, I am no goblin.
I’m a mendicant waiting for alms.’
‘Die, mendicant’s father! Die, mendicant’s mother!

segments.pli: Varaṁ te, bhikkhu, tiṇhena govikantanena kucchi parikanto, na tveva varaṁ yaṁ rattandhakāratimisāyaṁ kucchihetu piṇḍāya carasī’ti.
segments.en: Better to have your belly sliced open with a sharp meat cleaver than to wander for alms in the dark of night for the sake of your belly!’

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, tadanussarato evaṁ hoti:
segments.en: Recollecting that, I thought,

segments.pli: ‘bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā dukkhadhammānaṁ apahattā, bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā sukhadhammānaṁ upahattā;
segments.en: ‘The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!

segments.pli: bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ apahattā, bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upahattā’”ti.
segments.en: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!’”

segments.pli: “Evameva panudāyi, idhekacce moghapurisā ‘idaṁ pajahathā’ti mayā vuccamānā te evamāhaṁsu:
segments.en: “This is exactly what happens when some silly people are told by me to give something up. They say,
‘What, such a trivial, insignificant thing as this? This ascetic is much too strict!’

segments.pli: Te tañceva nappajahanti, mayi ca appaccayaṁ upaṭṭhāpenti.
segments.en: They don’t give it up, and they nurse bitterness towards me;

segments.pli: Ye ca bhikkhū sikkhākāmā tesaṁ taṁ, udāyi, hoti balavaṁ bandhanaṁ, daḷhaṁ bandhanaṁ, thiraṁ bandhanaṁ, apūtikaṁ bandhanaṁ, thūlo, kaliṅgaro—
segments.en: and for the mendicants who want to train, that becomes a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.

segments.pli: seyyathāpi, udāyi, laṭukikā sakuṇikā pūtilatāya bandhanena baddhā tattheva vadhaṁ vā bandhaṁ vā maraṇaṁ vā āgameti.
segments.en: Suppose a quail was tied with a vine, and was waiting there to be injured, caged, or killed.

segments.pli: Yo nu kho, udāyi, evaṁ vadeyya:
segments.en: Would it be right to say that,

segments.pli: ‘yena sā laṭukikā sakuṇikā pūtilatāya bandhanena baddhā tattheva vadhaṁ vā bandhaṁ vā maraṇaṁ vā āgameti, tañhi tassā abalaṁ bandhanaṁ, dubbalaṁ bandhanaṁ, pūtikaṁ bandhanaṁ, asārakaṁ bandhanan’ti;
segments.en: for that quail, that vine is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial?”

segments.pli: sammā nu kho so, udāyi, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

segments.en: “No, sir.

segments.pli: Yena sā, bhante, laṭukikā sakuṇikā pūtilatāya bandhanena baddhā tattheva vadhaṁ vā bandhaṁ vā maraṇaṁ vā āgameti, tañhi tassā balavaṁ bandhanaṁ, daḷhaṁ bandhanaṁ, thiraṁ bandhanaṁ apūtikaṁ bandhanaṁ, thūlo, kaliṅgaro”ti.
segments.en: For that quail, that vine is a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.”

segments.pli: “Evameva kho, udāyi, idhekacce moghapurisā ‘idaṁ pajahathā’ti mayā vuccamānā te evamāhaṁsu:
segments.en: “In the same way, when some silly people are told by me to give something up, they say,
‘What, such a trivial, insignificant thing as this? This ascetic is much too strict!’

segments.pli: Te tañceva nappajahanti, mayi ca appaccayaṁ upaṭṭhāpenti.

segments.en: and for the mendicants who want to train, that becomes a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.

segments.pli: Idha panudāyi, ekacce kulaputtā ‘idaṁ pajahathā’ti mayā vuccamānā te evamāhaṁsu:
segments.en: But when some gentlemen are told by me to give something up, they say,

segments.pli: ‘kiṁ panimassa appamattakassa oramattakassa pahātabbassa yassa no bhagavā pahānamāha, yassa no sugato paṭinissaggamāhā’ti?
segments.en: ‘What, we just have to give up such a trivial, insignificant thing as this, when the Blessed One tells us to give it up, the Holy One tells us to let it go?’

segments.pli: Te tañceva pajahanti, mayi ca na appaccayaṁ upaṭṭhāpenti.
segments.en: They give it up, and they don’t nurse bitterness towards me;

segments.pli: Ye ca bhikkhū sikkhākāmā te taṁ pahāya appossukkā pannalomā paradattavuttā migabhūtena cetasā viharanti.
segments.en: and when the mendicants who want to train have given that up, they live relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, their hearts free as a wild deer.

segments.pli: Tesaṁ taṁ, udāyi, hoti abalaṁ bandhanaṁ, dubbalaṁ bandhanaṁ, pūtikaṁ bandhanaṁ, asārakaṁ bandhanaṁ—
segments.en: For them, that bond is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.

segments.pli: seyyathāpi, udāyi, rañño nāgo īsādanto urūḷhavā abhijāto saṅgāmāvacaro daḷhehi varattehi bandhanehi baddho īsakaṁyeva kāyaṁ sannāmetvā tāni bandhanāni saṁchinditvā sampadāletvā yena kāmaṁ pakkamati.
segments.en: Suppose there was a royal bull elephant with tusks like chariot-poles, able to draw a heavy load, pedigree and battle-hardened. And it was bound with a strong harness. But just by twisting its body a little, it would break apart its bonds and go wherever it wants.

segments.pli: Yo nu kho, udāyi, evaṁ vadeyya:
segments.en: Would it be right to say that,

segments.pli: ‘yehi so rañño nāgo īsādanto urūḷhavā abhijāto saṅgāmāvacaro daḷhehi varattehi bandhanehi baddho īsakaṁyeva kāyaṁ sannāmetvā tāni bandhanāni saṁchinditvā sampadāletvā yena kāmaṁ pakkamati, tañhi tassa balavaṁ bandhanaṁ, daḷhaṁ bandhanaṁ, thiraṁ bandhanaṁ, apūtikaṁ bandhanaṁ, thūlo, kaliṅgaro’ti;
segments.en: for that bull elephant, that strong harness is a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke?”

segments.pli: sammā nu kho so, udāyi, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

segments.en: “No, sir.

segments.en: For that bull elephant, that strong harness is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.”

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, udāyi, puriso daliddo assako anāḷhiyo;
segments.en: Suppose there was a poor man, with few possessions and little wealth.

segments.pli: tassassa ekaṁ agārakaṁ oluggaviluggaṁ kākātidāyiṁ naparamarūpaṁ, ekā khaṭopikā oluggaviluggā naparamarūpā, ekissā kumbhiyā dhaññasamavāpakaṁ naparamarūpaṁ, ekā jāyikā naparamarūpā.
segments.en: He had a single broken-down hovel open to the crows, not the best sort; a single broken-down couch, not the best sort; a single pot for storing grain, not the best sort; and a single wifey, not the best sort.

segments.pli: So ārāmagataṁ bhikkhuṁ passeyya sudhotahatthapādaṁ manuññaṁ bhojanaṁ bhuttāviṁ sītāya chāyāya nisinnaṁ adhicitte yuttaṁ.
segments.en: He’d see a mendicant sitting in meditation in the cool shade, their hands and feet well washed after eating a delectable meal.
He’d think,

segments.pli: ‘sukhaṁ vata bho sāmaññaṁ, ārogyaṁ vata bho sāmaññaṁ.
segments.en: ‘The ascetic life is so very pleasant! The ascetic life is so very healthy!

segments.pli: So vatassaṁ yohaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
segments.en: If only I could shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

segments.pli: So na sakkuṇeyya ekaṁ agārakaṁ oluggaviluggaṁ kākātidāyiṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya, ekaṁ khaṭopikaṁ oluggaviluggaṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya, ekissā kumbhiyā dhaññasamavāpakaṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya, ekaṁ jāyikaṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajituṁ.
segments.en: But he’s not able to give up his broken-down hovel, his broken-down couch, his pot for storing grain, or his wifey—none of which are the best sort—in order to go forth.

segments.pli: Yo nu kho, udāyi, evaṁ vadeyya:
segments.en: Would it be right to say that,

segments.pli: ‘yehi so puriso bandhanehi baddho na sakkoti ekaṁ agārakaṁ oluggaviluggaṁ kākātidāyiṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya, ekaṁ khaṭopikaṁ oluggaviluggaṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya, ekissā kumbhiyā dhaññasamavāpakaṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya, ekaṁ jāyikaṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajituṁ;
segments.en: for that man,

segments.pli: tañhi tassa abalaṁ bandhanaṁ, dubbalaṁ bandhanaṁ, pūtikaṁ bandhanaṁ, asārakaṁ bandhanan’ti;
segments.en: those bonds are weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial?”

segments.pli: sammā nu kho so, udāyi, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?

segments.en: “No, sir.

segments.pli: Yehi so, bhante, puriso bandhanehi baddho, na sakkoti ekaṁ agārakaṁ oluggaviluggaṁ kākātidāyiṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya, ekaṁ khaṭopikaṁ oluggaviluggaṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya, ekissā kumbhiyā dhaññasamavāpakaṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya, ekaṁ jāyikaṁ naparamarūpaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajituṁ;
segments.en: For that man,

segments.pli: tañhi tassa balavaṁ bandhanaṁ, daḷhaṁ bandhanaṁ, thiraṁ bandhanaṁ, apūtikaṁ bandhanaṁ, thūlo, kaliṅgaro”ti.
segments.en: they are a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.”

segments.pli: “Evameva kho, udāyi, idhekacce moghapurisā ‘idaṁ pajahathā’ti mayā vuccamānā te evamāhaṁsu:
segments.en: “In the same way, when some silly people are told by me to give something up, they say,
‘What, such a trivial, insignificant thing as this? This ascetic is much too strict!’

segments.pli: Te tañceva nappajahanti, mayi ca appaccayaṁ upaṭṭhāpenti.
segments.en: They don’t give it up, and they nurse bitterness towards me;

segments.pli: Ye ca bhikkhū sikkhākāmā tesaṁ taṁ, udāyi, hoti balavaṁ bandhanaṁ, daḷhaṁ bandhanaṁ, thiraṁ bandhanaṁ, apūtikaṁ bandhanaṁ, thūlo, kaliṅgaro.
segments.en: and for the mendicants who want to train, that becomes a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, udāyi, gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo, nekānaṁ nikkhagaṇānaṁ cayo, nekānaṁ dhaññagaṇānaṁ cayo, nekānaṁ khettagaṇānaṁ cayo, nekānaṁ vatthugaṇānaṁ cayo, nekānaṁ bhariyagaṇānaṁ cayo, nekānaṁ dāsagaṇānaṁ cayo, nekānaṁ dāsigaṇānaṁ cayo;
segments.en: Suppose there was a rich householder or householder’s child, affluent, and wealthy. He had a vast amount of gold ingots, grain, fields, lands, wives, and male and female bondservants.

segments.pli: so ārāmagataṁ bhikkhuṁ passeyya sudhotahatthapādaṁ manuññaṁ bhojanaṁ bhuttāviṁ sītāya chāyāya nisinnaṁ adhicitte yuttaṁ.

He’d think,

segments.en: And he is able to give up his vast amount of gold ingots, grain, fields, lands, wives, and male and female bondservants in order to go forth.

segments.en: “In the same way, when some gentlemen are told by me to give something up, they say,

segments.pli: ‘kiṁ panimassa appamattakassa oramattakassa pahātabbassa yassa no bhagavā pahānamāha, yassa no sugato paṭinissaggamāhā’ti?
segments.en: ‘What, we just have to give up such a trivial, insignificant thing as this, when the Blessed One tells us to give it up, the Holy One tells us to let it go?’

segments.pli: Te tañceva pajahanti, mayi ca na appaccayaṁ upaṭṭhāpenti.
segments.en: They give it up, and they don’t nurse bitterness towards me;

segments.pli: Ye ca bhikkhū sikkhākāmā te taṁ pahāya appossukkā pannalomā paradattavuttā migabhūtena cetasā viharanti.
segments.en: and when the mendicants who want to train have given that up, they live relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, their hearts free as a wild deer.

segments.pli: Tesaṁ taṁ, udāyi, hoti abalaṁ bandhanaṁ, dubbalaṁ bandhanaṁ, pūtikaṁ bandhanaṁ, asārakaṁ bandhanaṁ.
segments.en: For them, that bond is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.

segments.pli: Cattārome, udāyi, puggalā santo saṁvijjamānā lokasmiṁ.
segments.en: Udāyī, these four people are found in the world.
What four?

segments.pli: Idhudāyi, ekacco puggalo upadhipahānāya paṭipanno hoti upadhipaṭinissaggāya.
segments.en: Take a certain person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.

segments.pli: Tamenaṁ upadhipahānāya paṭipannaṁ upadhipaṭinissaggāya upadhipaṭisaṁyuttā sarasaṅkappā samudācaranti.
segments.en: As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them.

segments.pli: So te adhivāseti, nappajahati, na vinodeti, na byantīkaroti, na anabhāvaṁ gameti.
segments.en: They tolerate them and don’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

segments.pli: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, udāyi, puggalaṁ ‘saṁyutto’ti vadāmi no ‘visaṁyutto’.
segments.en: I call this person ‘fettered’, not ‘detached’.
Why is that?

segments.pli: Indriyavemattatā hi me, udāyi, imasmiṁ puggale viditā.
segments.en: Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.

segments.pli: Idha panudāyi, ekacco puggalo upadhipahānāya paṭipanno hoti upadhipaṭinissaggāya.
segments.en: Take another person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.

segments.en: They don’t tolerate them, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

segments.pli: Imampi kho ahaṁ, udāyi, puggalaṁ ‘saṁyutto’ti vadāmi no ‘visaṁyutto’.
segments.en: I also call this person ‘fettered’, not ‘detached’.

segments.en: Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.

segments.en: Take another person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.

segments.pli: Tamenaṁ upadhipahānāya paṭipannaṁ upadhipaṭinissaggāya kadāci karahaci satisammosā upadhipaṭisaṁyuttā sarasaṅkappā samudācaranti;
segments.en: As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them every so often, due to the loss of mindfulness.
Slowly mindfulness arises,

segments.pli: Atha kho naṁ khippameva pajahati, vinodeti, byantīkaroti, anabhāvaṁ gameti.
segments.en: then they quickly give up, get rid of, eliminate, and obliterate those thoughts.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, udāyi, puriso divasaṁsantatte ayokaṭāhe dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni nipāteyya;
segments.en: Suppose there was an iron cauldron that had been heated all day, and a person let two or three drops of water fall onto it.

segments.pli: dandho, udāyi, udakaphusitānaṁ nipāto. Atha kho naṁ khippameva parikkhayaṁ pariyādānaṁ gaccheyya.
segments.en: Slowly the drops fall, but then they quickly dry up and evaporate.

segments.en: In the same way, take a person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.

segments.pli: Idha panudāyi, ekacco puggalo ‘upadhi dukkhassa mūlan’ti—
segments.en: Take another person who, understanding that attachment is the root of suffering,

segments.pli: iti viditvā nirupadhi hoti, upadhisaṅkhaye vimutto.
segments.en: is freed with the ending of attachments.

segments.pli: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, udāyi, puggalaṁ ‘visaṁyutto’ti vadāmi no ‘saṁyutto’ti.
segments.en: I call this person ‘detached’, not ‘fettered’.

segments.en: Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.

segments.en: These are the four people found in the world.
Udāyī, these are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
What five?

segments.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā,
segments.en: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
Sounds known by the ear …
Smells known by the nose …
Tastes known by the tongue …

segments.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā.
segments.en: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

segments.pli: Yaṁ kho, udāyi, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṁ somanassaṁ idaṁ vuccati kāmasukhaṁ miḷhasukhaṁ puthujjanasukhaṁ anariyasukhaṁ, na sevitabbaṁ, na bhāvetabbaṁ, na bahulīkātabbaṁ; ‘bhāyitabbaṁ etassa sukhassā’ti vadāmi.
segments.en: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure—a filthy, ordinary, ignoble pleasure. Such pleasure should not be cultivated or developed, but should be feared, I say.

segments.pli: Idhudāyi, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati
segments.en: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption …

segments.pli: vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati,
segments.en: second absorption …

segments.pli: pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati,
segments.en: third absorption …

segments.pli: sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: fourth absorption.

segments.pli: Idaṁ vuccati nekkhammasukhaṁ pavivekasukhaṁ upasamasukhaṁ sambodhasukhaṁ, āsevitabbaṁ, bhāvetabbaṁ, bahulīkātabbaṁ; ‘na bhāyitabbaṁ etassa sukhassā’ti vadāmi.
segments.en: This is called the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening. Such pleasure should be cultivated and developed, and should not be feared, I say.

segments.pli: Idhudāyi, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
segments.en: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption.

segments.pli: idaṁ kho ahaṁ, udāyi, iñjitasmiṁ vadāmi.
segments.en: This belongs to the perturbable, I say.
And what there belongs to the perturbable?

segments.pli: Yadeva tattha vitakkavicārā aniruddhā honti idaṁ tattha iñjitasmiṁ.
segments.en: Whatever placing of the mind and keeping it connected has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.

segments.pli: Idhudāyi, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
segments.en: Take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption.

segments.pli: idampi kho ahaṁ, udāyi, iñjitasmiṁ vadāmi.
segments.en: This belongs to the perturbable, I say.
And what there belongs to the perturbable?

segments.pli: Yadeva tattha pītisukhaṁ aniruddhaṁ hoti idaṁ tattha iñjitasmiṁ.
segments.en: Whatever rapture and bliss has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.

segments.pli: Idhudāyi, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
segments.en: Take a mendicant who, with the fading away of rapture, enters and remains in the third absorption.

segments.pli: idampi kho ahaṁ, udāyi, iñjitasmiṁ vadāmi.
segments.en: This belongs to the perturbable.
And what there belongs to the perturbable?

segments.pli: Yadeva tattha upekkhāsukhaṁ aniruddhaṁ hoti idaṁ tattha iñjitasmiṁ.
segments.en: Whatever bliss with equanimity has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.

segments.pli: Idhudāyi, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
segments.en: Take a mendicant who, giving up pleasure and pain, enters and remains in the fourth absorption.

segments.pli: idaṁ kho ahaṁ, udāyi, aniñjitasmiṁ vadāmi.
segments.en: This belongs to the imperturbable, I say.

segments.pli: Idhudāyi, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
segments.en: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption.

segments.en: But this is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
And what goes beyond it?

segments.en: Take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption. That goes beyond it.

segments.en: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space. That goes beyond it.

segments.en: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
And what goes beyond it?

segments.pli: Idhudāyi, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati, ayaṁ tassa samatikkamo;
segments.en: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. That goes beyond it.

segments.pli: idampi kho ahaṁ, udāyi, ‘analan’ti vadāmi, ‘pajahathā’ti vadāmi, ‘samatikkamathā’ti vadāmi.
segments.en: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
And what goes beyond it?

segments.pli: Idhudāyi, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati, ayaṁ tassa samatikkamo;
segments.en: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness. That goes beyond it.

segments.pli: idampi kho ahaṁ, udāyi, ‘analan’ti vadāmi, ‘pajahathā’ti vadāmi, ‘samatikkamathā’ti vadāmi.
segments.en: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
And what goes beyond it?

segments.pli: Idhudāyi, bhikkhu sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati, ayaṁ tassa samatikkamo;
segments.en: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. That goes beyond it.

segments.pli: idampi kho ahaṁ, udāyi, ‘analan’ti vadāmi, ‘pajahathā’ti vadāmi, ‘samatikkamathā’ti vadāmi.
segments.en: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
And what goes beyond it?

segments.pli: Idhudāyi, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja viharati, ayaṁ tassa samatikkamo;
segments.en: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. That goes beyond it.

segments.pli: iti kho ahaṁ, udāyi, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanassapi pahānaṁ vadāmi.
segments.en: So, Udāyī, I even recommend giving up the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

segments.pli: Passasi no tvaṁ, udāyi, taṁ saṁyojanaṁ aṇuṁ vā thūlaṁ vā yassāhaṁ no pahānaṁ vadāmī”ti?
segments.en: Do you see any fetter, large or small, that I don’t recommend giving up?”
“No, sir.”
That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Attamano āyasmā udāyī bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.
segments.en: Satisfied, Venerable Udāyī approved what the Buddha said.

sutta.blurb: Again raising the rule regarding eating, but this time as a reflection of gratitude for the Buddha in eliminating things that cause complexity and stress. The Buddha emphasizes how attachment even to little things can be dangerous.
